{{Short description|Canadian singer-songwriter (1940–2016)}} {{More citations needed|date=March 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Ray Griff | image = Ray Griff.png | caption = Griff in 1969 | image_size = 250px | background = solo_singer | alias = | birth_name = John Raymond David Griff | birth_date = {{Birth date|1940|4|22}} | birth_place = [[Vancouver, British Columbia]], Canada | death_date = {{Death date and age|2016|3|9|1940|4|22}} | instrument = Vocals | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | occupation = Singer-songwriter | years_active = 1964–2016 | label = [[Dot Records|Dot]], [[Capitol Records|Capitol]], [[GRT Records|GRT]] | past_member_of = [[George Hamilton IV]], [[Jerry Lee Lewis]] | website = }} '''John Raymond David Griff'''{{cite news |url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/calgaryherald/obituary.aspx?pid=178108618 |title= John Griff obituary|date= March 19, 2016 |newspaper=[[Calgary Herald]]|access-date=October 17, 2016}} (April 22, 1940 – March 9, 2016){{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p187400|pure_url=yes}} |title=Ray Griff biography |access-date=2008-09-25 |last=Demalon |first=Tom |work=[[Allmusic]]}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.yatesfuneral.ca/obits/obituary.php?id=594907|title=John GRIFF Obituary - Parksville|date=27 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160427072807/http://www.yatesfuneral.ca/obits/obituary.php?id=594907|access-date=7 August 2021|archive-date=2016-04-27}} was a Canadian [[country music]] singer and songwriter, born in Vancouver and raised in [[Toronto]]. His songwriting credits reached over 2500 songs, many of which were recorded by Nashville's top recording artists. ==Early life and career== Griff was born in [[Vancouver, British Columbia]], Canada {{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|page=167}} and raised in [[Winfield, Alberta]].{{cite news |url= http://www.fyimusicnews.ca/articles/2016/03/11/rip-canadian-country-star-ray-griff |last= Delaney |first= Larry |title= RIP: Canadian Country Star Ray Griff |date= March 11, 2016 |publisher=FYI Music News|access-date=October 17, 2016}} He began songwriting in the early 1960s and had early cuts by [[Johnny Horton]], [[Jim Reeves]], and others. Griff moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] in 1964 to pursue his music career full-time. His first records as a singer were released in the late 1960s and Griff had his first hit, "[[Patches (Chairmen of the Board song)|Patches]]", a remake of the [[Clarence Carter]] soul hit in 1970 which peaked at No. 26 in ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''. Griff recorded for the small country label Royal American and later moved on to [[Dot Records]] without much success. His stint at [[Capitol Records]] from 1975 to 1979 proved more successful, racking up eight more country top 40 hits, the most successful being 1976's "If I Let Her Come In" which peaked at No. 11. Griff's success as a songwriter, however, always overshadowed his recording work with over 700 songs recorded, including the major hits "[[Canadian Pacific (song)|Canadian Pacific]]" for [[George Hamilton IV]], "Who's Gonna Play This Old Piano" for [[Jerry Lee Lewis]], and "Baby" for [[Wilma Burgess]]. Others who had major hit records with Griff songs include [[Faron Young]], [[Porter Wagoner]] & [[Dolly Parton]], [[Bob Luman]], [[Gene Watson]], and [[Johnny Duncan (country music artist)|Johnny Duncan]]. Griff returned to Canada in the late 1970s and remained active on the country music scene there as an artist, songwriter, and record producer. He lived a quiet life in Calgary, Alberta, occasionally performing at country venues with musicians from the area, most notably the Ranchman's Inn. ==Later years== In 2008, Griff was awarded the Lifetime Achievement Award by [[SOCAN]] at the annual SOCAN Awards in Toronto.{{Cite web|url=http://www.socan.ca/about/awards/2008-socan-awards|title=2008 SOCAN AWARDS | SOCAN|date=10 August 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160810135616/http://www.socan.ca/about/awards/2008-socan-awards|access-date=7 August 2021|archive-date=2016-08-10}} Griff had battled throat cancer in his recent years, and he died on March 9, 2016, from pneumonia following surgery. He was 75.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rodeocountryradio.com/country-news/nde74xav5uw5et1pd6iik1j8gd4ttn|title="Ray Griff, dead at age 75"|website=Rodeocountryradi.com|date=March 10, 2016}}{{cite news |url=https://calgaryherald.com/entertainment/music/legendary-calgary-country-gentleman-ray-griff-dies-at-the-age-of-75 |last=Bell|first=Mike |title= Legendary Calgary 'country gentleman' Ray Griff dies at the age of 75|date= March 11, 2016 |newspaper=[[Calgary Herald]]|access-date=June 10, 2016}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable" !Year !Album !width=45|[[Top Country Albums|US Country]] !Label |- |1968 |''A Ray of Sunshine'' |align="center"|42 |rowspan=4|Dot |- |rowspan=2|1972 |''The Entertainer'' |align="center"|— |- |''Ray Griff Sings!'' |align="center"|— |- |1973 |''Songs for Everyone'' |align="center"|22 |- |1974 |''Expressions'' |align="center"|47 |ABC/Dot |- |rowspan=2|1976 |''Ray Griff'' |align="center"|31 |rowspan=3|Capitol |- |''The Last of the Winfield Amateurs'' |align="center"|44 |- |1977 |''Raymond's Place'' |align="center"|— |- |1978 |''Ray's Bar and Grill'' |align="center"|— |rowspan=5|Boot-London |- |1979 |''Canada'' |align="center"|— |- |1980 |''Maple Leaf'' |align="center"|— |- |1981 |''Adam's Child'' |align="center"|— |- |1982 |''Greatest Hits'' |align="center"|— |- |1983 |''You Can Count on Me'' |align="center"|— |rowspan=3|RCA |- |1984 |''You'' |align="center"|— |- |1985 |''The Sky's the Limit'' |align="center"|— |- |1987 |''My Kind of Country'' |align="center"|— |Bookshop |- |1988 |''Ray Griff & Friends: Honest to Goodness Amigos'' |align="center"|— |Warner Music Canada |- |1990 |''There'll Always Be Christmas'' |align="center"|— |ATI |- |1993 |''Ray Griff: Through the Years, Vol. 1 & 2'' |align="center"|— |Focus |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style=text-align:center; !
